hints.content: Start by identifying the vowels in the string. Remember that vowels include both lowercase and uppercase letters: 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u' and their uppercase counterparts.
Create a list to store the positions of the vowels as you iterate through the string. This will help you know where to place the sorted vowels later.
While iterating through the string, collect the vowels into a separate list. You can use a simple condition to check if a character is a vowel.
Once you have extracted the vowels, sort this list. You can use built-in sorting functions, which will handle the ASCII value sorting for you.
After sorting the vowels, prepare to reconstruct the string. You'll need to iterate through the original string again and replace the vowels with the sorted ones at their respective positions.
Make sure to keep track of which sorted vowel to insert next. You can use an index to reference the sorted vowel list as you build the new string.
Consider edge cases, such as when the string contains no vowels at all. In such cases, the output should be the same as the input string.
Pay attention to the constraints: the length of the string can be up to 100,000 characters. Ensure your solution is efficient, ideally O(n log n) due to sorting.
Remember that consonants should remain in their original positions. Make sure your reconstruction logic correctly handles this aspect.
Finally, think about how you will return the result. You should construct a new string from the characters you've placed, ensuring it matches the required format.

questionNotes: Vowels are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u' in both lowercase and uppercase.
Consonants remain in their original positions.
The output string must maintain the same length as the input string.
If there are no vowels, return the original string.
